next.name: The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight

segments.en: Linked Discourses 36
3. The Explanation of the Hundred and Eight
21. With Sīvaka

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

segments.pli: Atha kho moḷiyasīvako paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
segments.en: Then the wanderer Moḷiyasīvaka went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.

segments.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho moḷiyasīvako paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

segments.pli: “santi, bho gotama, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
segments.en: “Master Gotama, there are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

segments.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetū’ti.
segments.en: ‘Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds.’
What does Master Gotama say about this?”
“Sīvaka, some feelings stem from bile disorders.

segments.pli: Sāmampi kho etaṃ, sīvaka, veditabbaṃ yathā pittasamuṭṭhānānipi idhekaccāni vedayitāni uppajjanti.
segments.en: You can know this from your own personal experience,

segments.pli: Lokassapi kho etaṃ, sīvaka, saccasammataṃ yathā pittasamuṭṭhānānipi idhekaccāni vedayitāni uppajjanti.
segments.en: and it is generally agreed to be true.

segments.pli: Tatra, sīvaka, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
segments.en: Since this is so, the ascetics and brahmins whose view is that

segments.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetū’ti.
segments.en: everything an individual experiences is because of past deeds

segments.pli: Yañca sāmaṃ ñātaṃ tañca atidhāvanti, yañca loke saccasammataṃ tañca atidhāvanti.
segments.en: go beyond personal experience and beyond what is generally agreed to be true.
So those ascetics and brahmins are wrong, I say.
Some feelings stem from phlegm disorders …
wind disorders …
their conjunction …
change in weather …
not taking care of yourself …
overexertion …

segments.pli: kammavipākajānipi kho, sīvaka, idhekaccāni vedayitāni uppajjanti.
segments.en: Some feelings are the result of past deeds.
You can know this from your own personal experience,
and it is generally agreed to be true.

segments.pli: tatra, sīvaka, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
segments.en: Since this is so, the ascetics and brahmins whose view is that

segments.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetū’ti.
segments.en: everything an individual experiences is because of past deeds

segments.pli: Yañca sāmaṃ ñātaṃ tañca atidhāvanti yañca loke saccasammataṃ tañca atidhāvanti.
segments.en: go beyond personal experience and beyond what is generally agreed to be true.
So those ascetics and brahmins are wrong, I say.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, moḷiyasīvako paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When he said this, the wanderer Moḷiyasīvaka said to the Buddha,

segments.pli: “abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṃ, bho gotama … pe …
segments.en: “Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent! …

segments.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
segments.en: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
“Bile, phlegm, and wind,
their conjunction, and the weather,
not taking care of yourself, overexertion,
and the result of deeds is the eighth.”

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha,…

suttaplex.blurb: When the wanderer Moḷiyasīvaka asks if all feelings are caused by karma in past lives. The Buddha denies this, asserting that feelings have many different causes.
